section.title: Present Continuous (for future arrangements)
section.sectiontitle: Use the Present Continuous to talk about personal arrangements or fixed plans in the future. They often involve other people and the time/place has been arranged.
section.text1a: When are you starting your job?
section.text2a: She isn't coming to my birthday party.
section.sectiontitle2: Going to and the Present Continuous can express similar ideas. Choose depending on what you mean.
section.text3a: I'm going to see Phil again. (you have made a decision but no arrangement)
section.text4a: I'm seeing Phil tonight at the tennis club. (you have made an arrangement with Phil)

section.title: Present Continuous (for future arrangements)
section.sectiontitle: With the verbs go and come, it is generally better to use the Present Continuous.
section.text1a: I am going to Australia when I have enough money.
section.text2a: My brother is coming to see me next weekend.
